MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1975 TO 31ST MARCH, 1976

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head P (cont.) -

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head P be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CBA 1109.

    Sir, how far has the work progressed at the Bedok Cut Site, and when will the reservoir be built at the Cut Site?

    What measures are being taken to clear our canals of filth, and what action has been taken against offenders who pollute the rivers, canals and drains, although there is a general improvement in the cleanliness of most rivers and

Column: 660

canals? I have observed that Rochore Canal is often heavily polluted with rubbish and oil and clearing up operations are slow and poor. As a result, it continues to smell badly.

    It is a common sight to see a considerable amount of rubbish floating down the Singapore River to the sea. Sometimes you can even see large boxes and huge pieces of rubbish floating down to the sea. Why is this important river allowed to be left like that? This is definitely unsightly to our tourists. I hope the Minister will look into this matter.

    What steps are being taken to improve the drainage around Newton, Kampung Java and Farrer Park areas? During the rainy season, these places are usually flooded. Since this is a central point between Bukit Timah/Thomson Road and the City, office workers always have a problem during rainy seasons. This problem has been going on for many years. Can something concrete be done about it?

Column: 661



    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the excavation work at Bedok is undertaken by the Housing and Development Board, and according to the schedule the work will be completed by the end of 1975. As regards the question of building a reservoir there, a feasibility study is being made to find out whether the soil can hold water. Construction of a reservoir will depend upon the result of the study and the soil test.

    I am glad to hear the Member for Anson say that there has been an improvement in the general cleanliness of our canals and rivers, with the exception of one or two. It should be so because we have spent $800,000 on contract labour for the financial year 1973-74 to maintain and desilt canals and rivers. In addition, we have our own fleet of 14 excavators to clean our watercourses of silt and refuse. It is a slow and unpleasant job, and it will take some time before we can clean all our rivers. But there is improvement. There will be more improvement if members of the public stop polluting the canals. The odour which the Member complained about is the result of pollution. There is still a good number of irresponsible people who persist in throwing rubbish into rivers and canals, though 9.800 offenders were taken to court last year for polluting our watercourses.

    Regarding flooding at Newton and Kampung Java areas, I think there has been a great improvement in these areas. The duration of the floods is shorter now and frequency of flooding is less. This is because Phase I of the project to improve the Bukit Timah Canal has been completed. Phase II is under study. It will take quite a long time to complete the work, and it is going to cost a lot of money. There are other matters which require priority and it will be some time before flooding can be totally eradicated from these areas.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am satisfied with the Minister's explanation but I would like to request that these canals be kept under frequent observation. The Minister cannot blame

Column: 662

the people for polluting the canals because we cannot control them. If the people are disciplined and do not throw rubbish into the rivers and canals, there is no need to employ cleaners. Anyway, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn. The following amendment stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting -

    (6) That the sum to be allocated for Head P be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 4002.

    The Chairman: Mr Ng Kah Ting is not moving.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head P be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BAA 2110.

    The beaches around Singapore are one of the very few places where people can go to relax. Unfortunately, certain beaches are in a deplorable condition. To give an example, the beach at the end of Sembawang has not got even a single litter bin. In fact, the whole beach is littered. Pieces of glass are strewn all over the sand, and is a danger to picnickers.

    Furthermore, patches of oil are regularly found around this beach. Obviously they come from the shipyard which is just a short distance away. Since a good crowd of picnickers and swimmers go to this beach, why cannot we look after the beach and keep it clean? Maintenance can thus be summed up in one word "nil". Let us do something about it so that our citizens in that corner of the island are not completely neglected.

    However, I am pleased to say that the grass cutters have kept the grass in that particular area neat and obviously trimming has been done so often that it is the reverse in the case of the cemeteries at Chua Chu Kang.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot reconcile what the Member said just now. On the one hand, he said that on that particular beach "maintenance can be summed up in one word `nil' ". But then he went on to say that "However, I am pleased to say that the grass

Column: 663

cutters have kept the grass in that particular area neat", so there is maintenance.

    The deplorable condition of the beach is because people are irresponsible or careless. They continue to ignore the no-littering signs. Perhaps the Member was there when picnickers may have dirtied the place again immediately after the cleaners have completed cleaning. So I cannot accept the statement that there has been no maintenance. There has been maintenance but no amount of maintenance can prevent what he called "this deplorable condition". This deplorable condition is the result of littering by some people who use it.

    However, I think the long-term solution lies in educating the public. Until the public change their habits, no amount of litter bins, beach cleansing work and enforcement action can keep our beaches completely free of litter.

    There is no litter bin in the particular beach which the Member mentioned because when the tide is high it covers the beach. So there is no point in putting a litter bin only to see it float away later.

    On the complaint of oil sludge, may I inform the Member for Anson that the shipyard concerned has its own facilities for reception of oil sludge. The PSA also has its own facilities at Pulau Sebarok for removing oil sludge from tankers and ships. The PSA has also been taking enforcement action against sea pollution. We are at the crossroad between East and West, and hundreds of ships pass by daily. Some of the ships may have discharged their oil sludge while passing through without being caught. This is the price we have to pay for being in the centre of a very busy trading route. But whatever can be done is being done to prevent pollution of our sea.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, regarding the Minister's reply about the litter bins floating away, I would like to suggest that the bins be fixed to long poles and then bury these poles firmly in the

Column: 664

beach. In this way, the bins cannot float away. I am sure this can be done.

    Anyway, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head P be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BCA 2110.

    Sir, most probably after listening to me the Minister for the Environment will get angry again.

    We have had a very active anti-mosquito breeding campaign. Yet at the Chua Chu Kang Cemetery the conditions are such that it is an excellent breeding ground for mosquitoes. At the entrances to the cemetery there are notices forbidding the use of flower vases on the graves. This is to avoid the collection of rain water which will then be a breeding place for mosquitoes.

    But as you walk further you find lalang all over the place, as high as the waist. If I am not mistaken, in the burial ceremony of a Catholic priest, on 24th June, 1974, a great number of mourners had to fight through lalang as tall as a man, and thick undergrowth. To make matters worse, there were many muddy potholes and pools of water all over the place - ideal for mosquitoes to breed. Such conditions make it difficult for anyone to move about in a burial ceremony or in paying respects to the dead. Surely, something can be done to improve this poor state of affairs at the cemeteries.

    Sir, are the plots for burials dug deep enough? They seem to be too shallow. A terrible smell pervades the air because of the shallow graves. Are the graves really six feet deep or are the grave diggers taking things a bit easy?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson has given a poetic description of the graveyard and its surroundings. I am glad to note that in his description there is no mention of his coming across mosquitoes in spite of the fact that he had to make his way

Column: 665

through muddy potholes of water. This is because anti-mosquito measures are being actively carried out all the time all over Singapore.

    Chua Chu Kang cemetery is one of the many places constantly checked for mosquito breeding. This cemetery is 900 acres in extent. Only part of it is developed. Lalang and undergrowth are cleared at four-weekly intervals, that is, once a month. However, there may be occasions when rainfall is heavier than usual, and this will cause them to grow faster than normal. Hence, the burial ceremony mentioned by the Member for Anson must have taken place near an undeveloped piece of land and at a time when clearing of lalang was due.

    While I can appreciate his very imaginative description of fighting through waist-high lalang and hacking through undergrowth, I must however accept it with a pinch of salt. However,' let me assure the Member for Anson that instructions have been given to my officers to see that the paths to the graves are smooth and clean.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, graves are not dug six feet deep. They are dug five feet deep, according to regulations. The Superintendent of Cemeteries is there to see that this regulation is observed when the grave diggers do their work. In addition, lime is added to the fill to prevent smell.

    Perhaps we can take it as a fact that public conveniences for men and women are usually quite a distance away from the burial site. I believe it could be that perhaps someone had to answer the call of nature at about the time he was there.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, on a point of clarification, if the Minister will give way.

    Mr Lim Kim San resumed his seat.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the graves do actually give out an odour, especially those that are freshly dug and burials done within one or two weeks. I can substantiate what my good Friend, the Member for Anson, has said, regarding the odour. I have been there several times and I know

Column: 666

that this is true. I think it is most likely that this is due to the condition of the soil in that particular area of Chua Chu Kang rather than what has been vividly described by the Minister as "the call of nature". I think it has something to do with the soil. I am not an expert, but it is a fact that some of the graves do smell.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been my unfortunate experience during the last few months to have to attend quite a number of funerals. I have always thought that I have a sensitive nose, but I have not come across the smell that has been described. It could be that others have a more sensitive nose than I and the explanation given by the Member for Punggol is probably true. I have asked my officers but they cannot confirm it. However, it is possible that since the soil is loose after a grave is dug, the smell of decomposition might seep through the soil. But it takes a really keen nose to sense it. Anyway, if this is so, we will make further investigations and may insist on a deeper burial in the case of soil of this nature.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has not answered the point about lalang. As soon as lalang is cut, it grows again after two or three days. To stop it, lalang must be uprooted and not cut, otherwise it grows again.

    Regarding the smell, the explanation is this. The lalang is about six feet high. The grave diggers can only dig three or four feet deep because the lalang is very high. The grave is also not deep and, therefore, the smell comes out. The main fault is the lalang. The Minister should go there and then only will he know what is going on. I am saying that this is a fact. If the Minister goes to that place he will then know it. It is a long distance away, and perhaps the Minister is unable to go there.

    An hon Member: He has no time.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: The Minister has no time. But everybody must go there. One day he must go there too, if he is free. According to Hindu custom,

Column: 667

the Indians cremate their dead. But now, our Government has adopted the use of gas for cremation. The Buddhists and Christians usually bury their dead. Even among the Hindus too, a certain group does not cremate those who die young. They are buried. All these matters must be considered. The main thing is that I am telling this House that the problem of lalang is very important. Once the lalang is fully uprooted, everything will be all right, the soil will be very clean. Anyway, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head P be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead RCA 8101.

    Sir, I wish to raise two questions under this subhead. The Hawkers Department has spent a great deal of money on the construction of hawker centres to accommodate the hawkers in sanitary conditions for them to do their business, instead of in the open where they are exposed to the elements. The policy is good. But the design and construction of hawker centres, particularly the quality of materials, are open to question, and I doubt whether such an objective can be achieved. For example, in my constituency one hawker centre was built with very old building materials. In other words, old materials have been used for the construction of a new hawker centre. As a result, there are holes in the roofs and gutters and the pillars are very shaky. When it rains, water pours down through openings in the roof, and consequently the whole hawker centre is flooded on rainy days. On a sunny day the stalls along the sides of the hawker centre are completely exposed to the sun. They cannot do business in the sun. When the hawkers want to put up tarpaulin, they do not get the permission.

    As regards the design of the stalls in the hawker centres, I find that the size and space of the stalls are becoming smaller and smaller. They cannot meet

Column: 668

the requirements of the hawkers. If the hawkers want a larger wash basin or a wash tub, there is not enough space. So most hawkers prefer to have a clear empty space for a pitch than a stall with all sorts of amenities that restrict free movement. What I am trying to say is that if it is the intention of the Government to help hawkers by spending so much money on them then we should build some decent hawker centres which are practical and will meet their requirements. The hawkers will then be grateful to the Government for putting up a very fine hawker centre.

    In this regard, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister some questions concerning the Corporation Drive Hawker Centre I that was newly constructed in Jurong. When will repair and renovation be made to this hawker centre? When will the leaky roof and gutters be changed or repaired? I would also like to ask the Minister whether a proper awning will be put up on one side of this hawker centre so as to provide shade for the stalls from the sun.

    One or two years ago a lot of licences were issued to hawkers, that is to say, hawkers were put under control by licensing. Once licences are issued, hawkers have to pay a licence fee. Pork sellers have to pay $30 per month, payable quarterly at $90 per quarter. For other types of stalls, the fee is $10 per month, payable quarterly. The licensed hawkers who ply on the roadside also have to pay a licence fee but they do not enjoy all the privileges that they are supposed to have. For instance, they do not have water supply. Sir, hawkers require water for cleaning and washing and to keep the place clean. This is a reasonable request that should be granted. I fail to see why the Hawkers Department has refused to grant this reasonable request for water supply. I, therefore, ask the Minister to explain.

3.00 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir, the Member for Jurong has raised

Column: 669

a few questions in regard to hawker centres, in particular to Taman Jurong Market I. His criticism is that the design and the construction of the particular centre is far from ideal. I am sure he with agree with me that human beings are always making progress and are therefore always faced with problems, many of which have no solution. That is to say, human beings live in changing circumstances. So we may have taken a different view of a certain matter after a while. This particular market extension may be far from ideal because it was one of the first few to be constructed.

    In Jurong there are two markets, viz. Taman Jurong Market I and Market II. Between the two, there is a lot of difference both in design and in construction. The second one was built completely on the basis of a new design. The first one that the Member referred to was actually a conversion of the existing cooked food section. So in the process of conversion, some old materials might have been used. That is admitted. As regards roof leaks, we have already notified the contractors to take the necessary action for repairs to be effected or improvements to be made.

    Sir, I would also like to answer another point that the Member has raised. He says that the facilities in some hawker centres are not suitable. Most of the hawker centres are meant for cooked food and there is a great variety of food stalls, some selling drinks, some selling cooked food. Different types of food stalls require different facilities. But in the planning of such facilities, we can only provide facilities to meet the general requirements of hawkers, based on certain broad principles.

    As regards the Member's complaint that the stall is too small, I cannot see eye to eye with him. Changes and improvements are made from time to time, and we find that the stall's dimensions are becoming bigger and bigger. For example, the original stall measured 6 feet by 4 feet. The improved type is 9 feet by 7 feet which is very much bigger.

Column: 670



    Sir, the Government subsidises hawker centres very heavily. The licence fee for a cooked food stall is only $50 and yet we hear a lot of complaints and grumbles. On the other hand hawkers who are not licensed have to pay through their nose for a very small lousy stall in a coffee shop. This stall measures only 3 feet by 4 feet and the rent ranges from $100 to $300! $400 per month. Not only that, such stallholders in coffee shops are subject to a lot of restrictions imposed by the coffee shop owners. Quite often they are asked to quit. But in the case of Government controlled hawker stalls, the hawkers have a lot of complaints to make. If they really have so many complaints and grumbles, the best advice I can give is that they should get their own private stalls which can meet their own ideal requirements. This is my own personal view.

    Sir, as regards leaky roofs and hawker stalls exposed to the sun and the elements, we have several times consulted the architects responsible for the design, and a lot of improvements and changes have since been made. In cooked food hawker centres, there is a lot of smoke when food is being cooked. In a tropical country like Singapore, if the roof is completely covered then ventilation can be very poor and the whole hawker centre will be so stuffy and hot, and it will be very uncomfortable. Then there will be more complaints again. There must be provision for suitable ventilation and therefore we have provided openings and holes at the sides of the roofs. So, a little bit of splash on a rainy day is quite inevitable, because the hawker centres are not completely covered and sealed. In the mornings and afternoons when the sun is shining obliquely, a certain portion of the hawker centre is exposed to the sun. This is perfectly all right. I am sure we cannot have a complete perfectly designed hawker centre to meet the ideals of everyone.

    Sir, as regards hawkers whose requests have not been met, I would like to say that generally we accommodate their requests as far as we possibly can. In regard to water supply, the PUB is in

Column: 671

charge, and it is not a matter for the Ministry of the Environment to handle alone. So we must have consultations to come to an arrangement with other relevant departments or ministries. But, generally speaking, whatever it is I am sure Members of this House will agree with me that, according to a Chinese saying, it is difficult to establish a business from scratch but it is even more difficult to maintain it. This is a problem that everybody, including a government, has to face. As the saying goes, good advice is unpleasant to the ear, so is good medicine bitter to the tongue.

    However, I would like to say to the Members who have spoken, that although they have made criticisms, some of them are constructive suggestions with good intentions, and I would like to thank them for all that has been said.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): Sir,I am grateful to the Parliamentary Secretary for saying so much on how one should behave in life and about life in general. But he has not directly answered the points that I have raised. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary is good in tai-chi. He has admitted in his reply that the particular hawker centre that I referred to was built with old materials, which resulted in so many problems. So my question is: since it is the intention of the Government to look after the welfare of hawkers, why did they not adopt the improved design and use new materials? If they feel that a fully covered roof results in poor ventilation, then they could have planned a higher roof for the hawker centre. Why must they keep the roof to a very low level? This is the crux of the problem. My question is: when will repairs be made to this particular hawker centre? And no answer has been given yet.

    The second question I raised, Sir, refers to the supply of water, which is the basic facility required by hawkers. They may not ask for anything else.

Column: 672

They pay a monthly licence fee and all they ask for is some water. The Senior Parliamentary Secretary says it is because of the problem of management, etc. Those are minor problems which can be easily solved. If there is any particular problem about management, I can help him to make arrangements to ensure that there is no wastage of water by any hawker. Therefore, I would like to ask him again whether arrangements can be made for water to be supplied to licensed hawkers on the streets.

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Sir, I think the best is for me to arrange a date with the Member for Jurong for an on-the-spot check to see how the problem can be solved. If that is agreeable, I believe he should be satisfied?

    Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): Sir, I accept the Parliamentary Secretary's invitation. For the moment, because of the time factor, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Head Q -

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Q be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1004(The same amendment also stood in the same names of Messr Eng Siong and Govindaswamy).

    Under this subhead I would like to raise the point about the need for a clearer definition of our cultural policy. This would be useful for various sectors involved in cultural activity to orientate themselves towards. Such sectors are the Ministry of Education, voluntary cultural bodies, teachers of the arts, institutions like the Music Department of the University of Singapore, the People's Association, the National Theatre, RTS, and even the Ministry of Culture itself.

    Cultural development seems to me to occupy a rather uncertain place in the general pattern of Singapore's development plans. And yet such development

Column: 673

is so important for nation-building and giving people a sense of community and solidarity. Here I take cultural development to mean development of the means and facilities providing access and participation in relation to culture. Presently, what are the rather blurred lines of policy that can be discerned especially according to budgetary allocation for cultural development. We find that there is good support for broadcasting and publicity. The rationale here is evident for this relates to communication between the government and the people. But other sectors within the portfolio of the Ministry of Culture do not seem, at least to me, Sir, to be receiving adequate attention in terms of financial support. Good support for art, for example, had to await the generosity and the initiative of the Singapore Arts Council. Contributions to cultural organisations have gone down suddenly from $110,000 to $20,000. In respect of cultural cooperation even expenses related to the ASEAN Permanent Committee on socio-cultural activities have been pruned slightly from $20,000 to $15,000.

3.15 p.m.

    Another example of rather indifferent attention to aspects related to cultural development is the question of the low grading for the post of the Director of the National Museum and inadequate support for the work of the Museum although it should be seen as a repository of the nation's cultural heritage, as a fine centre of display to interpret effectively to the community the meaning of our heritage, and as a centre of activities of a cultural, educational and recreational nature.

    Another line we can discern is that we subscribe to the notion that culture is not for the elite as judged from our activities like music and art for everyone, concert for the young people, and also from the activities of the People's Association. Yet after saying these things we could still ask what other projections, what plans for development do we have, what attempts are we going to make to bring our cultural tradition up to date and in harmony with our needs and

Column: 674

aspirations Static culture is dead culture but we are very much alive as a people.

    For any kind of vigorous development in the cultural field, money is required. To make rich contributions to our culture, I am not speaking in terms of money here, we cannot rely on the development of amateur talent, as we have in the past. We must work towards having an adequate core of professional artistes especially for music and dance, and regular and organised effort has to be planned for the encouragement of the development of talent for drama, writing and song.

    In any attempt at projection one has to know clearly what we have at present. Indeed, it is possible to select cultural indicators and study them and make an essay of what we have presently and what we could do to improve the situation. These cultural indicators, apart from relating to the number of books in libraries, the number of radio and television sets there are, can also be represented by percentages of the population taking part in cultural activities, numbers of students of the arts, the proportion of the budget allocated to culture and the proportion of the cultural budget allocated to different aspects of culture, and so on. Culture is so important to national development that it is about time that systematic modes of examination are applied to our cultural situation for the purposes of projection of plans for cultural development.
